text: Great question! Thanks for the sites too

elements.text: Great question! Thanks for the sites too

text: Hi all, I wanted to get some advice on rates raising them/asking for more. I have been working with a consulting agency for about 6 months in my writing process and they are currently doing a huge shift on one of their websites which the writing requires more research and deep than the work before. I am thinking it may be time to approach them with asking for more per article given the process is now longer and more technical in nature. Anyone have any advice how to do so gracefully and respectfully?

elements.text: Hi all, I wanted to get some advice on rates raising them/asking for more. text:
How far do you guys niche down in your agency? 

When I look around at other local agencies their niches are usually by industry but no more specific than that and I was curious what your perspective and retrospection has been

elements.text:
How far do you guys niche down in your agency? 

When I look around at other local agencies their niches are usually by industry but no more specific than that and I was curious what your perspective and retrospection has been

text: Hello! Not all of our members are guys. In an effort to be more conscious of the language we use to address each other, why not try “Hey, folks,” or “Hey everyone” instead?

Following, because this happens to once a year or more. Sometimes, if I know that the budget isn't there (they are letting people go, raising prices on their own products), I know what they will say, and I prepare to find work so that I can replace them when they inevitably say "no" after I ask. Really significant scope creep can be a sign of dysfunction, at least that's what I've witnessed over the years. For them to think it's OK to ask this of you makes me think someone else may be calling the shots or they don't have the same mission as when they brought you on. Good luck with this. I hate when it happens.

Really significant scope creep can be a sign of dysfunction, at least that's what I've witnessed over the years. For them to think it's OK to ask this of you makes me think someone else may be calling the shots or they don't have the same mission as when they brought you on. Good luck with this. I hate when it happens.

text: Also following - I have one client who gives me incredibly specific detailed briefs that are near-impossible to fulfil. I originally quoted my usual rate of $220 for an article but I got to around 1000 words with the last one and still hadn't covered everything she asked for. Now I'm not sure how to go back and say 'hey these are really complex and you need all these extra citations and references, so I need to charge more.' Mind you, they sell cleaning products so it's quite difficult to get super-granular about toilet cleaner :expressionless:
